title: Sofia Vergara ordered to pay $80,000 to ex in frozen embryo battle
text:
Sofia has been ordered to pay attorney costs (Picture: Getty)

Sofia Vergara has been ordered to pay her ex $80,000 (£61,000) in legal fees amidst a legal battle over her embryos.

The Modern Family actress is involved in a legal row with her ex-fiance Nicholas Loeb, who previously sought to obtain full custody of two pre-embryos they created together through IVF.

Loeb filed a motion for attorney’s fees in June 2019, asking a judge for $117,590.17 (£90,198.72) in attorney fees and $2,958.26 (£2,260.38) in costs from his ex.

Loeb claimed that he was successful in his anti-SLAPP motion (which provides for early dismissal of meritless lawsuits) as it related to a ‘malicious prosecution claim’.

Nicholas wants custody of the two embryos (Picture: Venturelli/Getty Images)

However, Vergara, 47, argued the motion ‘should be denied or heavily reduced to the extent it is based on block billing and seeks fees and costs for services not shown to be related to the successful portion of the anti-SLAPP motion’.

A judge ruled that the billing records didn’t justify the fees sought by Loeb, and applied a 35% reduction – meaning Vergara has been ordered to pay to $79,392.26 (£60,871.63), with $76,433 (£58,601.95) in attorney’s fees and $2,959.26 (£2,260.82) in costs.

Sofia and Nicholas began dating in 2010 and got engaged two years later, before splitting in 2014.

Rich Fury/Getty Images for Maui Film Festival )

However, before this, the couple looked into using IVF and a surrogate to have a child together.

Before starting IVF, Vergara and Loeb signed an agreement that said one person could not use the cryopreserved material to create a child without the explicit written consent of the other.

Two embryos were created and remain in cryogenic storage at the ART Reproductive Center.

In December 2016, a right-to-live lawsuit was taken against Vergara by three plaintiffs, Vergara’s embryos, named ‘Emma’ and ‘Isabella’, and their ‘trustee’ James Charbonnet.

Loeb requested custody of the embryos in order for them to live and ultimately inherit a trust fund set up in their names.

The case was dismissed in Louisiana – a pro-life state – in 2017 as the embryos were created in California.

Sofia, who has a 27-year-old son Manolo from a previous relationship, is now married to True Blood star Joe Manganiello.
